description:
Hi
I am using devstack (current master branch, may be of havana release) and launched an instance from "cirros" image as following:-

+--------------------------------------+----------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
| ID                                   | Name     | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks                       |
+--------------------------------------+----------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
| eb251761-50f0-4a00-9062-a572ff7af834 | CIRROS-1 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     |       private=10.0.0.2      |

Now I deleted the fixed ip using below CLI:-

$$ nova remove-fixed-ip CIRROS-1 10.0.0.2

And it removed fixed ip successfully:-
+--------------------------------------+----------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
| ID                                   | Name     | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks                       |
+--------------------------------------+----------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
| eb251761-50f0-4a00-9062-a572ff7af834 | CIRROS-1 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     |                                        |

Now I again want to add fixed_ip and tried many times using below CLIs:-
$$nova  add-fixed-ip CIRROS-1 10.0.0.4
$$nova  add-fixed-ip CIRROS-1 10.0.0.2

But above CLIs neither give error nor allocate fixed_ip to instance.

I tried it with both user i.e. demo and admin, and also try to ping that IPs but not working.
title: Single fixed_ip allocated to an instance can be deleted and not assigned again on request

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~sourabh-chordiya

comments.content:
Hi Saurabh,

At first there is something wrong that you are using the add-fixed-ip command. The usage is:
# nova add-fixed-ip <server> <network-id>
the second parameter is network-id not ip address.

there is nothing wrong with the add-fixed-ip command. 
However, there are really something wrong with this function. the virtual machine can only get one ip address through DHCP even you add multiple ip address to that virtual machine. From this perspective, we need to get nova-network/neutron to support multiple ip address on one port.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ljjjustin

comments.content:
Hi jiajun,

Thanks for the information.
Yes, you are right I used wrong parameter.
Now I test it again and it is working, I can add many fixed ip on virtual machine successfully.

But there is one problem that  you mentioned  already that "the virtual machine can only get one ip address through DHCP even you add multiple ip address to that virtual machine."172.16.0.

I see one more strange behaviour that if a virtual machine have IP address suppose 172.16.0.7 and I add another fixed IP address 172.16.0.6 to it, then it got IP address which is small in number.
For example if my virtual  machine have IP address 172.16.0.7, now if I add another IP address 172.16.0.8, then in that case it works only with 172.16.0.7,
but if I add another IP address 172.16.0.6(which is smaller than 172.16.0.7) then it works only with 172.16.0.6 not with 172.16.0.7 (means  172.16.0.7 is removed)
What is your opinion on it, is it correct behaviour of DHCP server?

In my opinion allocated IP should not been deallocated from virtual machine until someone delete it.

comments.content:
The return code is 202 and is returned before its known if the operation has succeeded or not. 

Defintion for 202 is " The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing has not been completed. The request may or may not eventually be acted upon, as it may be disallowed when processing actually takes place. there is no facility for status returns from asynchronous operations such as this. "
